item.title: Borderlands 4 Narrative Director Doesn't Want Skibidi Or Hawk Tuah Jokes In Game
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/borderlands-4-narrative-director-doesnt-want-skibidi-or-hawk-tuah-jokes-in-game/1100-6528514/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There might be toilets in Borderlands 4, but the game's narrative director loathes the idea of this leading to skibidi jokes. This is all part of trying to cut back on the "overabundance of toilet humor" from Borderlands 3, according to Sam Winkler.

Eurogamer noticed that the Borderlands 4 narrative director was discussing the tone of the upcoming game on X. Winkler replied to one question about how he was critical of Borderlands 3's toilet humor and then voiced his thoughts on including recent internet sensation jokes. "I'm not gonna say there's no toilets, but if the word skibidi ships in the game under my watch, I'm gonna cry real tears," said Winkler. "[Forbes writer] Paul Tassi joked that we were gonna have a gun called Hawk 2A, and a fellow dev asked me if it was real, and I wanted to put my hand down the sink grinder."

I’m not gonna say there’s no toilets but if the word skibidi ships in the game under my watch I’m gonna cry real tears. Paul Tassi joked that we were gonna have a gun called Hawk 2A and a fellow dev asked me if it was real and I wanted to put my hand down the sink grinder

— Sam Winkler (@ThatSamWinkler) December 16, 2024

At The Game Awards last week, Gearbox unveiled the first gameplay trailer for the looter-shooter. Borderlands 4 will feature a seamless world and new movement mechanics that will "make it hard for players to go back," according to creative director Graeme Timmins.

Last month, a terminally ill fan got to check out Borderlands 4 early, courtesy of a wish fulfilled by Gearbox. Caleb McAlpine thought "it was awesome" and thanked everyone for making the experience a possibility.

Borderlands 4 is set to launch next year for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Moana's Maui Coming To Disney Speedstorm, You're Welcome
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/moanas-maui-coming-to-disney-speedstorm-youre-welcome/1100-6528506/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Disney Speedstorm is finally starting to get characters from Moana, with the addition of the demigod Maui as a playable racer. The trailer shows off the Speedstorm makeover for the character with his own racing suit and themed car, along with a handful of his special moves.

As you might expect, Maui is a Trickster class. Tricksters have more Boost than other classes, and can gain nitro fuel by drifting. They also tend to get skills like Hack or Bomb. Maui's unique skill is called Hero to All. The standard version uses his magical fishhook to deliver a huge explosion, while in the charged version, he shapeshifts into a hawk to counterattack and speed past opponents.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Disney Speedstorm - Exclusive Maui Racer Reveal Trailer

The trailer notes that Maui is available now, and teases that Moana herself will be coming soon too. Like Maui, she appears to have gotten her own Speedstorm makeover and car, with a similar appearance to Maui's. Her skills were not detailed in this trailer.

Disney Speedstorm is a kart racer featuring characters from across a wide swath of Disney properties--the Mickey Mouse family of characters, animated films like Frozen and Toy Story, live-action movies like Pirates of the Caribbean, and even tangential properties like the Muppets. New seasons rotate in roughly every month, and the current season features five characters from The Incredibles films: Mr. Incredible, Mrs. Incredible, Violet, Dash, and Frozone.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Witcher 4 Devs Seemingly Tease That Gwent Will Be In The Game
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-witcher-4-devs-seemingly-tease-that-gwent-will-be-in-the-game/1100-6528512/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Earlier this month, CD Projekt Red finally shared the first look at The Witcher 4 with a new teaser featuring Ciri as a fully fledged Witcher on her own adventure. And while there wasn't much time for fun and frivolity in that preview, the developers are hinting that the card game Gwent will be featured in the upcoming sequel.

Game director Sebastian Kalemba and executive producer Gosia Mitręga were asked about Gwent's presence in The Witcher 4 during their joint interview with Easy Allies. While neither Kalemba nor Mitrega came right out and said Gwent is in the game, they certainly seemed to confirm it.

"We really love [Gwent], and we also really carefully, always listen to the community⁠--which we love--and it's an amazing one. But I don't think anyone will be disappointed," said Mitrega. "It's a part of the experience, absolutely," agreed Kalema. "We also love Gwent."

Gwent was featured extensively in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, and its popularity among players led CD Projekt Red to release a standalone title, Gwent: The Witcher Card Game. Near the beginning of December, Hachette Boardgames UK and No Loading Games announced plans to release Gwent as a physical tabletop game with a deck of 400 cards and a playmat. It's expected to be released in late 2025.

The Witcher 4 doesn't currently have a release date, and CD Projekt Red only recently ramped up its team to over 400 developers and officially began production. Kalemba also shared a scene-by-scene breakdown of the teaser trailer, which sheds more light on Ciri's actions and dropped hints about a potentially different outcome than the one fans witnessed in the preview.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: CD Projekt Red Recast The Witcher 4's Leading Role
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cd-projekt-red-recast-the-witcher-4s-leading-role/1100-6528511/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt marked the first appearance of Princess Ciri of Cintra in the game series that was inspired by Andrzej Sapkowski's fantasy novels. Ciri had a big role role the third game, and as seen in the first teaser for The Witcher 4, she's going to be the main character in the next title. However, sharp-eared players may have already picked up on the fact that CD Projekt Red has recast Ciri for her upcoming starring role.

CD Projekt Red confirmed TheGamer's report that Irish actress Ciara Berkeley voiced Ciri in the teaser trailer, and she will portray the heroine in The Witcher 4 as well. Jo Wyatt previously voiced Ciri in The Witcher 3 and its DLC. Berkeley only has a handful of credits to her name, including the TV miniseries Swing Bout, The Deceived, and Normal People. A spokesperson for CD Projekt Red told The Gamer that "Ciara is a talented actress who impressed us with her enthusiasm and vocal acting skills, and in this trailer we believe she truly brought Ciri to life in a way that is both faithful to the character and exciting for fans of the series."

There may potentially be other parts that are recast in the game, but Doug Cockle will be back as Ciri's mentor Geralt. Earlier this summer, Cockle confirmed that Geralt will be a part of the next game, although he later walked back his comments shortly before the teaser reveal at The Game Awards. Geralt's voice was heard at the end of the teaser that streamed during the ceremony, but not in the standalone trailer on YouTube.

The Witcher 4 game director Sebastian Kalemba recently shared a breakdown of the first teaser, which included details about the monster that Ciri was hunting as well as the young woman that she was trying to save. The scenes that played out in the trailer will be a part of The Witcher 4's narrative, and Kalemba hinted that players may be able to change the outcome in Ciri's favor.

CD Projekt Red hasn't announced a release date for The Witcher 4 yet.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
